p: Greek writers reported the use of cannabis for dressing sores and wounds in humans and horses [ 34]. The dried leaves were used against nosebleeds and the seeds against tapeworms. The green seeds were steeped in a liquid such as water or a variety of wine, pressed out, warmed and then instilled into the ear for pains and inflammation associated with blockages [ 34]. The “Berlin Hippiatrica”, a collection of horse remedies, indicates the chopped leaves were used to dress a wound. First some vinegar and pitch were brought to a full rolling boil, then wax, mustard, wheat-chaff, and roasted pine-resin were added, and the resulting mixture (presumably cooled) was applied liberally, then chopped cannabis leaves and grass trimmings were put on top before the wound was bound [ 35].
